title: Rodents Are Gay
historical_context: This article reflects the hacker culture of the late 1980s, where public personas and credibility were paramount. It showcases the rivalry and scrutiny within the hacking community.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article features a satirical interview with a self-proclaimed hacking expert, Codes Master, exposing his lack of knowledge and credibility in the hacking community. It serves as a humorous critique of posers in the scene.
summary:
In 'Rodents Are Gay', R.A.G. presents a tongue-in-cheek interview with Codes Master, a figure in the hacking community who claims expertise in Primos systems. The interview reveals Codes' questionable knowledge and the absurdity of his self-promotion, as he is confronted with inconsistencies in his claims. The dialogue is filled with sarcasm and highlights the culture of skepticism that existed among hackers during this era. The article ultimately serves to ridicule Codes Master, portraying him as a 'poser' who attempts to infiltrate the hacking community without the requisite skills or experience.

The piece is not just a personal attack but also a commentary on the importance of credibility and authenticity in the hacking world. It reflects the competitive nature of the community, where reputation can be easily tarnished by exposure. The humorous tone and absurdity of the interview make it an entertaining read, while also providing insight into the dynamics of hacker culture in the late 1980s. This article remains relevant as it underscores the ongoing issues of credibility and authenticity in online communities.
